liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said on Thursday the risk of regional spillover from the Israel-Hamas war is "real." Speaking at the Hudson Institute in Washington, Ms von der Leyen also said dialogue between Israel and its neighbours must continue. "We have seen the Arab streets fill with rage all across the region. So the risk of a regional spillover is real," she said. "Iran, Hamas's patron, only wants to fuel the fire of chaos. Russia, Iran's war-time customer, is watching carefully. Russia and Hamas are alike," the EU leader said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: European Commission President: 'The risk of a regional spillover is real'

children.content: European Commission President
Ursula von der Leyen
said on Thursday the risk of regional spillover from the Israel-Hamas war is "real."
Speaking at the Hudson Institute in Washington, Ms von der Leyen also said dialogue between Israel and its neighbours must continue.
"We have seen the Arab streets fill with rage all across the region. So the risk of a regional spillover is real," she said.
"Iran, Hamas's patron, only wants to fuel the fire of chaos. Russia, Iran's war-time customer, is watching carefully. Russia and Hamas are alike," the EU leader said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As Israel's ground offensive into the Gaza Strip looks imminent, the humanitarian crisis looks set to worsen for the almost 2.3 million people already under siege. Speaking to News Breakfast from Ashdod, the ABC's global affairs editor John Lyons predicted Israel forces would go into the strip within the next 24 hours. "The feeling here is that the US has given the green light that President Biden has basically signed off on it," he said. "He had that condition that he wanted a humanitarian corridor into Egypt along the Rafah crossing. That is going to happen. "The feeling here in Israel is they're ready to go. " Humanitarian agencies feared any aid allowed in would not be near enough following days of Israeli bombardment. "One thing that really brought it home to me was Gaza's rescue services put out a statement yesterday saying that we have so much on our plate that there are hundreds of people still buried alive under some of the rubble and we're not going to be able to get to all of them, " he said. "What a dreadful situation for those people caught under the rubble. They are still alive, but being told that sorry, we don't have enough people to get you out. The hospitals are chaotic. "It's a tragic situation already and on top of that … they're about to face the full wrath of the most powerful army. "
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The latest from global affairs editor John Lyons: 'The feeling here is they're ready to go'

children.content: As Israel's ground offensive into the Gaza Strip looks imminent, the humanitarian crisis looks set to worsen for the almost 2.3 million people already under siege.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden's visit to Israel on Wednesday produced a heaping dose of vocal support, a deal to get limited humanitarian aid into Gaza from Egypt (likely by the end of the week) and a plea for Israelis not to allow rage over the deadly Hamas attack to consume them. "I understand. Many Americans understand," Biden said as he wrapped up his stay in Tel Aviv, likening the October 7 Hamas terror attack to the attacks against the United States on September 11, 2001, that killed nearly 3,000 people. "You can't look at what has happened here … and not scream out for justice," he said. "But I caution this: While you feel that rage, don't be consumed by it. "After 9/11, we were enraged in the United States. And while we sought justice and got justice, we also made mistakes ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden wraps up Israel visit with a warning against being 'consumed' by rage

props.alt: Biden sits in front of Israeli and US flags.

children.content: Joe Biden.
(AP: Miriam Alster/pool)
US President
Joe Biden's

visit to Israel on Wednesday produced a heaping dose of vocal support, a deal to get limited humanitarian aid into Gaza from Egypt (likely by the end of the week) and a plea for Israelis not to allow rage over the deadly Hamas attack to consume them.

"I understand. Many Americans understand," Biden said as he wrapped up his stay in Tel Aviv, likening the October 7 Hamas terror attack to the attacks against the United States on September 11, 2001, that killed nearly 3,000 people.
"You can't look at what has happened here … and not scream out for justice," he said.
"But I caution this:
While you feel that rage, don't be consumed by it.
"After 9/11, we were enraged in the United States.
And while we sought justice and got justice, we also made mistakes

title.children: US Federal Reserve chair warns interest rates could rise again, Wall Street slides,  ASX set to open lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While most Aussies were sleeping, US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell was doing a lunchtime speech and question time at the Economic Club of New York. Climate activists delayed the start of the speech, with about half a dozen protesters taking to the stage, unfurling a large banner and chanting. Security apparently dimmed the lights and removed Mr Powell from the room. But, let's get back to what he actually said. He acknowledged steady progress on slowing inflation and the role of rising yields. Treasury yields have soared recently on expectation rates will be kept higher for longer, which could slow the economy. "We are attentive to recent data showing the resilience of economic growth and demand for labour. Additional evidence of persistently above-trend growth, or that tightness in the labour market is no longer easing, could put further progress on inflation at risk and could warrant further tightening of monetary polic y." Mr Powell also warned the Israel-Gaza war could impact the global economy. "A range of uncertainties, both old and new, complicate our task of balancing the risk of tightening monetary policy too much against the risk of tightening too little," he said. He also referred to the US government's huge debt (US debt has increased to $US33 trillion!). "We think that the US has an unsustainable path. Everyone knows that," Mr Powell said during the question and answer session. To sum up: the US economy's strength and continued tight labour markets could mean more rate rises are on the cards, however, the bond market is now doing some of the central bank's work for it (and might lessen the need for additional rate increases).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The lowdown on the US Federal Reserve chair's chat

children.content: While most Aussies were sleeping, US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell was doing a lunchtime speech and question time at the Economic Club of New York.
Climate activists delayed the start of the speech
, with about half a dozen protesters taking to the stage, unfurling a large banner and chanting.
Security apparently dimmed the lights and removed Mr Powell from the room.
But, let's get back to what he actually said.
He acknowledged
steady progress on slowing inflation
and the role of rising yields.
Treasury yields have soared recently
on expectation rates will be kept higher for longer, which could slow the economy.

"We are attentive to recent data showing the resilience of economic growth and demand for labour. Additional evidence of persistently above-trend growth, or that tightness in the labour market is no longer easing, could put further progress on inflation at risk and
could warrant further tightening of monetary polic
Mr Powell also
warned the Israel-Gaza war could impact the global economy
"A range of uncertainties, both old and new, complicate our task of balancing the risk of tightening monetary policy too much against the risk of tightening too little," he said.
He also referred to the US government's huge debt (US debt has increased to $US33 trillion!).
"We think that the US has an unsustainable path. Everyone knows that," Mr Powell said during the question and answer session.
To sum up:

the US economy's strength and continued tight labour markets could mean more rate rises are on the cards, however, the bond market is now doing some of the central bank's work for it (and might lessen the need for additional rate increases).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello there, I'm Emily Stewart and I'll be bringing you all the business and finance news today. It's looking like the local share market will open lower this morning, following a slide on Wall Street. All three major US stock indices faltered after the US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell said additional rate hikes could be warranted in view of economic resiliency and labour market tightness. 10-year US Treasury yields went up, reaching a 16-year high. Let's get through the final day of the working week together. Happy Friday!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Good morning!

children.content: Hello there,
I'm Emily Stewart and I'll be bringing you all the business and finance news today.

this morning, following a slide on Wall Street.

after the US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell said
additional rate hikes could be warranted
in view of economic resiliency and labour market tightness.
10-year US Treasury yields went up
, reaching a 16-year high.
Let's get through the final day of the working week together.
Happy Friday!
